comments:
I'm having trouble getting a 3.2 Platform to run under Solaris-Motif.  Am I missing some files I need to build?

I have an application built on the Eclipse Platform 3.1.2 that I'd like to upgrade to 3.2.  This application is deployed on Solaris-Motif and Windows (Solaris-Motif is the primary deployment platform; development is done exclusively under Windows).  I had set up a streamlined process for deploying only Eclipse distribution .JARS, which guarantees that what I'm deploying is consistent, but with 3.2 the Solaris-Motif binary distribution got dropped, so I have to build on Solaris now.  (Frankly, I don't understand this decision; if there's already a process for building it -- presumably automated to a great extent -- why drop it?  If it's a matter of support, why not just make the binaries available AS-IS?)  

It's really not practical to build the ENTIRE system from source just for one of the platforms supported, when 99% of it is already included in various distributions.  (Not to mention the fact that the whole POINT of using the Eclipse Platform -- or the RCP or any other toolkit, for the matter -- is to avoid having to manage the source in-house.)  So I do the following:

1) Copy the Solaris-GTK binary distribution to a new directory for Solaris-Motif.

2) From the source distribution, build a new eclipse executable (using the Sun ONE compiler -- I couldn't find any docs specifying which compiler to use, and GNU didn't compile properly) and overwrite the one in Solaris-Motif.  (Side note: I tried this with 3.1.2 and it worked, so I assume no additional compiler options are needed.)

3) In the configuration/config.ini, comment out the line with "osgi.ws=gtk"

4) Build a new org.eclipse.swt.motif.solaris.sparc_[ver].jar (where [ver] is the version specified for the "org.eclipse.swt.motif.solaris.sparc" plugin entry in the Solaris-Motif/features/org.eclipse.rcp_[ver]/feature.xml) as follows:
  a) From the source distribution, extract the plugins/org.eclipse.swt.motif.solaris.sparc directory
  b) From the SWT Solaris-Motif distribution, extract the swt.jar file and extract it to the the plugins/org.eclipse.swt.motif.solaris.sparc directory
  c) Delete the .project and build.* files from the plugins/org.eclipse.swt.motif.solaris.sparc directory
  d) Package the directory, using the MANIFEST.MF from the SWT Solaris-Motif distribution
  e) Add the new .JAR file to the Solaris-Motif/plugins directory

However, when I try to run Eclipse in this new Solaris-Motif directory, I get the following error:

java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.

Sorry, step 4d) should be: use the MANIFEST.MF from the source distribution.
Releng?  Can you either help this guy or bring back Solaris Motif?

Please use the source build for 3.2 (eclipse-sourceBuild-srcIncluded-3.2.zip) to build the SDK for solaris-motif-sparc.
Support is still included in the source build to create the drop, however this platform is not generated with the regular build because it is no longer 
included as a reference platform in the plan.

http://www.eclipse.org/eclipse/development/eclipse_project_plan_3_2.html

I think Eclipse is missing the point.

I UNDERSTAND that Eclipse is no longer including Solaris/Motif as a reference platform.  I UNDERSTAND that the source is included (I used it, remember?).  For the life of me, I don't understand why Eclipse won't supply the SWT plugin for Solaris/Motif, since it's still supported in the binary distributions of SWT.  (Or why it was dropped from the final release, when it was included in all the Miletone releases.)

Is it not obvious that requiring end users to build the Platform from source makes Eclipse useless as a third-party deployment framework?  Isn't the whole POINT of the Platform and RCP packaging to eliminate having to build Eclipse from source??

GTK is not an option; it's not installed by default on Solaris 8 or 9, which is in heavy use in government, which is our customer base.  (I believe the default is Motif even on Solaris 10).  There are a lot of environments (gov, banking, finance, to name just a few) where the users don't necessarily have the control to install new packages without a long line of approvals, if at all.  

As for the C compiler, if I have to purchase a rather expensive compiler just to build the launcher (it wouldn't compile under GCC, but it did compile under SunONE, which I just HAPPENED to have an old copy of laying around), then I would expect Eclipse to document that, as well.  (If it's documented somewhere, I couldn't find it.)

If Eclipse isn't going to support Solaris/Motif, fine, then just say so and don't pretend otherwise.  We'll stick on Eclipse 3.1.2 until we find a more amenable deployment Platform that supports Solaris/Motif.

If Eclipse IS going to support Solaris/Motif, then just tell me what I need to do to make the parts specific to Solaris/Motif, not the entire Platform.  That's all I'm asking.
I agree with Dan.  How about updating the RCP download?  SWT has not dropped support for Solaris Motif.
I'll bring up this issue at this weeks's arch call for discussion.
Approval garnered in arch call to add back to builds for RCP.  Requesting PMC +1 for inclusion in 3.2.1 builds.
Fixed released to HEAD and R3_2_maintenance stream for upcoming builds.

Created an attachment (id=60441)
Eclipse 3.2.1 launcher for Solaris SPARC/Motif

Just to clarify for those that run across this problem: the Eclipse launcher still must be built from source.  The resolution here is the restoration of the SWT plugin JAR for Solaris SPARC/Motif and the RCP package with it, but NOT the platform, which contains the launcher executable.

I had to use SunONE to compile the launcher; it?s possible it will work with GCC, but I don?t use GCC and I couldn?t get it to compile without the error message ?cannot specify ?o with ?c or ?S and multiple compilations?. 

So, in the spirit of helpful documentation, here are the steps I used to build the Solaris SPARC/Motif launcher executable with SunONE:

1) Download the Eclipse SDK Source Build distribution, eclipse-sourceBuild-srcIncluded-3.2.1.zip

2) Extract the launcher source ZIP: unzip eclipse-sourceBuild-srcIncluded-3.2.1.zip plugins/org.eclipse.platform/launchersrc.zip

3) Extract the launcher source: unzip plugins/org.eclipse.platform/launchersrc.zip ?d plugins/org.eclipse/platform

4) Change to the launcher source dir: cd plugins/org.eclipse.platform/library/motif

5) Set the compiler environment variable used by the .mak file to SunONE (shell-dependent): CC=[path_to_compiler_installation]/bin/cc

6) Link to the GNU make (it won?t work with SunONE?s make!): which gmake | sed ?s|\(.*\)|ln ?s \1 make|? | sh

7) Build the launcher in the current directory: sh build.sh

This builds a file named eclipse with the following dependencies on my system (from ldd):
            libXm.so.4 =>     /usr/lib/libXm.so.4
            libXt.so.4 =>     /usr/lib/libXt.so.4
            libX11.so.4 =>    /usr/lib/libX11.so.4
            libintl.so.1 =>   /usr/lib/libintl.so.1
            libc.so.1 =>      /usr/lib/libc.so.1
            libXext.so.0 =>   /usr/openwin/lib/libXext.so.0
            libdl.so.1 =>     /usr/lib/libdl.so.1
            libSM.so.6 =>     /usr/openwin/lib/libSM.so.6
            libICE.so.6 =>    /usr/openwin/lib/libICE.so.6
            libsocket.so.1 => /usr/lib/libsocket.so.1
            libnsl.so.1 =>    /usr/lib/libnsl.so.1
            libmp.so.2 =>     /usr/lib/libmp.so.2
            /usr/platform/SUNW,Sun-Blade-2500/lib/libc_psr.so.1

If you don?t have SunONE, based on the dependencies, the attached Eclipse 3.2.1 launcher binary might work on your system, but I'm not really a Unix programmer, so I can?t tell for sure.  If it doesn't work, I'm afraid someone else will have to figure out how to make the build work with GCC.
